title: Inside Rio Tinto‚Äôs most advanced mine
description:
Sky News Business Editor Edward Boyd has travelled to Rio Tinto‚Äôs Gudai-Darri mine in Western Australia to see the mining corporation's newest and most technologically advanced mine.

This is the first large-scale media trip Rio Tinto has hosted since the Juukan Gorge scandal ‚Äì which saw 46,000-year-old aboriginal shelters blown up by the company. 

The $3.1 billion Gudai-Darri mine began its production in 2021 and reached its capacity of 43 million tonnes in less than four months.

Rio Tinto plans to invest a further $130 million ‚Äì expanding the mine's output to 50 million tonnes. 

Gudai-Darri uses autonomous trucks, drills, water carts and trains ‚Äì as well as remote control robots that inspect conveyor belts for bearing failures and damage.

The driverless trucks only stop to be refuelled or serviced.

Thank you to our teams, suppliers, customers and partners for your support this year. We can‚Äôt wait for what 2025 has in store.

title: Why Mining Giant Rio Tinto Is Benefitting From The EV Boom
description:
Copper mines, like this one in Utah, are on the frontline of America‚Äôs transition to clean energy. This site, owned and operated by mining giant Rio Tinto, produces roughly 200,000 metric tons of copper annually ‚Äî with room to grow. Global demand for copper, a major component of EVs, is expected to almost double from 25 million metric tons to nearly 49 million metric tons by 2035. But miners face a multitude of issues as they ramp up production, not least of which includes mitigating environmental damage, addressing the concerns of the local stakeholders, and operating in remote regions of the world. 

Based in the UK, Rio Tinto is one of the world‚Äôs largest mining companies with projects in 35 countries. In addition to its 17 iron ore mines in Western Australia that produce material used in steel, its products include aluminum, diamonds, and boron, a component in fertilizer and smartphones. Historically miners have been known for their environmental impact but today are increasingly recognized as crucial players in the transition to green energy. So what is Rio Tinto doing to ramp up production of its critical minerals business and how will China‚Äôs economic slowdown impact its iron ore sector? CNBC got a behind the scenes look at Rio Tinto‚Äôs Utah operation to find out.

Chapters:
0:00-3:02 Intro 
3:02-6:25 Chapter 1 Kennecott
6:26-8:36 Chapter 2 History 
8:37-10:58 Chapter 3 Mining challenges 
10:59:13:30 Chapter 4 Automation in mining

title: Rio Tinto | Meet Kyle, a Maintenance Engineer at Gudai-Darri
description:
Kyle‚Äôs one of our Maintenance Engineers who moved from a remote town in Queensland, Australia, to one of our most technologically advanced operations, Gudai-Darri, in Western Australia.

‚ÄúThe University of Queensland's InspireU program I went on it back in 2015, and it‚Äôs just a great way to show Indigenous kids, or people from remote communities, about engineering and STEM. I guess it‚Äôs what made me decide to pursue a tertiary education, and I doubt if I didn‚Äôt (join the program) that I‚Äôd have gone to Uni. It‚Äôs a really good program,‚Äù Kyle said.

‚ÄúThe energy transition and what the future of mining is going to look like is changing for the better.‚Äù

title: Potential Rio Tinto-Glencore merger in the works
description:
Sky News Business Reporter Edward Boyd says Rio Tinto is already the second-largest mining company in the world. 

Mining giant Rio Tinto is reportedly holding merger talks with the global commodities trader Glencore. 

‚ÄúThe two, according to Bloomberg, are holding very early stages talks over a merger,‚Äù Mr Boyd said. 

‚ÄúFrom Rio Tinto‚Äôs perspective, they are really keen to buy more future-facing commodities; new sorts of assets, things like lithium.‚Äù

title: RIO TINTO‚ÄôS $200 MILLION-A-DAY MINE | LykeShares Explorer
description:
Every day, iron ore worth over $200 million leaves Western Australia‚Äôs red Pilbara desert.
This is Tom Price, the massive Rio Tinto mine that never stops moving rock.
Last year, Rio made $11 billion in profit, much of it from exports like this.
Unions say Australia‚Äôs losing billions in missed potential ‚Äî should we keep shipping raw ore, or start keeping more of the profit here?

title: Rio Tinto's New CEO: The Man Controlling a $100 BILLION Mining Empire
description:
There's a new leader at the helm of a $100 billion global mining empire. This video is a deep-dive investment analysis into the appointment of Simon Trott as the new CEO of Rio Tinto. We explore who Trott is and why this internal appointment is a critical signal to the financial markets.

As the former head of their most profitable iron ore division, what will his corporate strategy be? We'll analyze the future of Rio Tinto stock, the challenges of geopolitical risk, and his mandate to deliver shareholder value. This is an essential briefing for anyone interested in the commodities market, corporate leadership, and high-level business finance.
#RioTinto #CEO #Investing #Business #Finance

title: Rio Tinto receives approval for $34.3 billion iron ore project in West Africa
description:
Rio Tinto has received approval from the Guinean and Chinese governments to develop the $34.3 billion Simandou iron ore project in West Africa.

Production is expected to begin next year.

Rio Tinto will contribute about $9.2 billion in costs towards the development.

Once fully operational, Simandou will be able to export about 120 million tonnes of iron ore per year.

title: How Rio Tinto Uses DJI Dock for Smarter Mining Operations
description:
"Seamless." "Easy to implement." "Massive benefit."

That‚Äôs how Rio Tinto Gudai-Darri describes the shift to automated drone operations.

By deploying DJI Dock systems, their teams now conduct automated site monitoring that serves multiple departments, all without disrupting daily operations.

From trial to transformation, one mining site is proving what the future of industrial automation looks like.

See how automation and aerial data are transforming the mining industry üëâ https://brnw.ch/21wXhb6

description:

title: Rio Tinto | Upgrading our villages across the Pilbara in Western Australia
description:
We are on an on-going journey to building a safe, respectful and inclusive workplace for everyone, everywhere, everyday. 

It's been 2 years since we released the Everyday Respect Report and began implementing the 26 recommendations.

One of those recommendations was to identify and remedy any facilities at our sites found to be less than satisfactory; like assessing lighting and security.

We've been upgrading our villages across the Pilbara in Western Australia. Check out the üìΩÔ∏è to see some of the improvements. 

Find out more about the Everyday Respect Report: https://www.riotinto.com/en/sustainability/talent-diversity-inclusion/everyday-respect

title: Rio Tinto CEO on Guinea Project, China Demand, Strategy
description:
Rio Tinto Group Chief Executive Officer¬†Jakob Stausholm talks about the company's Simandou project in Guinea, China's economy and the nation's demand for commodities, and the mining giant's growth strategy. The world‚Äôs top iron ore exporter will spend about $6.2 billion on development of the vast project as it aims to deliver higher-quality raw material to steelmakers seeking to curb emissions. Stausholm speaks with Haidi Stroud-Watts on "Bloomberg Markets: Asia."
